title: In on a secret? Thatâ€™s dramatic irony - Christopher Warner

options.label: B
options.text: Verbal irony

options.label: C
options.text: Dramatic irony

options.label: D
options.text: Irony of fate

options.label: A
options.text: The villain reveals their plan to the hero

options.label: B
options.text: The hero discovers a hidden clue

options.label: C
options.text: The audience knows the villain is hiding behind a door, but the hero does not

options.label: D
options.text: The hero and villain engage in a fight

options.text: By making the audience feel like they are in on a secret

options.label: D
options.text: By resolving conflicts too quickly

options.text: Drama

options.label: D
options.text: Action

options.label: C
options.text: It makes them feel bored and uninterested

options.text: P-E-M-A-D-S

options.label: C
options.text: M-E-P-D-A-S

options.label: D
options.text: S-A-D-M-E-P

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the musketeers' efforts to defeat Puff the Magic Digit Dragon?

options.label: A
options.text: The dragon became even more powerful

options.label: B
options.text: The musketeers were defeated

options.label: C
options.text: The numbers of the kingdom were freed

options.label: D
options.text: The dragon was not affected

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the Emperor Number after the musketeers defeated Puff the Magic Digit Dragon?

options.label: A
options.text: He was restored to power

options.label: B
options.text: He was thrown into the mouth of an ancient nesting creature

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What Aristotle and Joshua Bell can teach us about persuasion - Conor Neill

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference in the audience's reaction to Joshua Bell's performance at the Symphony Hall and the subway station?

options.label: A
options.text: The music he played was different.

options.label: B
options.text: The audience at the Symphony Hall was more knowledgeable about music.

options.label: C
options.text: The ethos and pathos were missing in the subway station performance.

options.label: D
options.text: The audience at the subway station was in a hurry.

multiple-choice.question: According to Aristotle, what are the three means of persuasion?

options.label: A
options.text: Logos, ethos, and authority

options.label: B
options.text: Logos, ethos, and pathos

options.label: C
options.text: Ethos, pathos, and credibility

options.label: D
options.text: Logos, authority, and credibility

multiple-choice.question: What does "ethos" refer to in the context of persuasion?

options.label: A
options.text: The emotional connection with the audience

options.label: B
options.text: The credibility and reputation of the speaker

options.label: C
options.text: The logic and reasoning behind the argument

options.label: D
options.text: The authority and confidence of the speaker

multiple-choice.question: Why did the concert hall setting contribute to the audience's positive reaction to Joshua Bell's performance?

options.label: A
options.text: The concert hall was more convenient to get to.

options.label: B
options.text: The concert hall was a more intimate setting.

options.label: C
options.text: The concert hall transferred its trust to Joshua Bell.

options.label: D
options.text: The concert hall was a more formal setting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of "pathos" in persuasion?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a logical connection with the audience

options.label: B
options.text: To establish the credibility of the speaker

options.label: C
options.text: To create an emotional connection with the audience

options.label: D
options.text: To demonstrate authority and confidence

title: How to find the true face of Leonardo - Siegfried Woldhek

multiple-choice.question: What is the controversy surrounding Leonardo da Vinci's appearance?

options.label: A
options.text: There are no known portraits of him.

options.label: B
options.text: There are many conflicting descriptions of his appearance.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no consensus among historians about his face.

options.label: D
options.text: He never drew self-portraits.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker do to try to find Leonardo da Vinci's self-portraits?

options.label: A
options.text: He looked at all of Leonardo's writings.

options.label: B
options.text: He scanned all of Leonardo's drawings.

options.label: C
options.text: He consulted with other historians.

options.label: D
options.text: He visited museums and galleries.

multiple-choice.question: What characteristics did the speaker look for in potential self-portraits of Leonardo da Vinci?

options.label: A
options.text: Profiles and vague drawings.

options.label: B
options.text: Detailed drawings done as 3/4 views.

options.label: C
options.text: Caricatures and ugly faces.

options.label: D
options.text: Only paintings, not drawings.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's occupation that gave him expertise in analyzing faces?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a historian.

options.label: B
options.text: He was an artist who drew portraits.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a museum curator.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a writer.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reference used to confirm the identity of the faces in the potential self-portraits?

options.label: A
options.text: A painting by another artist.

options.label: B
options.text: A statue of Leonardo da Vinci as a boy.

options.label: C
options.text: A written description by a contemporary.

options.label: D
options.text: A photograph of a descendant.

title: A plant's-eye view - Michael Pollan

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker wants to convey about nature and our relationship with it?

options.label: A
options.text: That humans are the dominant species and should control nature.

options.label: B
options.text: That nature is a separate entity from human culture.

options.label: C
options.text: That humans are a part of nature and should work with it, not against it.

options.label: D
options.text: That nature is a resource to be exploited for human benefit.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "looking at the world from the plant's or animal's point of view" that the speaker discusses?

options.label: A
options.text: A scientific method for studying animal behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: A literary device for writing about nature.

options.label: C
options.text: A way of understanding the interconnectedness of species and their roles in the ecosystem.

options.label: D
options.text: A means of controlling and manipulating the natural world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example that the speaker gives of a farm that uses this perspective to create a more sustainable and productive system?

options.label: A
options.text: A large-scale industrial farm that uses advanced technology to maximize yields.

options.label: B
options.text: A small-scale organic farm that uses natural methods to control pests and diseases.

options.label: C
options.text: A farm that uses a symbiotic arrangement of different species to create a self-sustaining ecosystem.

options.label: D
options.text: A farm that relies on external inputs of fertilizers and pesticides to maintain productivity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using this perspective in agriculture, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased yields and profits.

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced environmental impact and increased biodiversity.

options.label: C
options.text: Improved animal welfare and reduced use of antibiotics.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about the relationship between humans and nature?

options.label: A
options.text: That humans are separate from nature and should dominate it.

options.label: B
options.text: That humans are a part of nature and should work with it, not against it.

options.label: C
options.text: That nature is a resource to be exploited for human benefit.

options.label: D
options.text: That humans have no impact on the natural world.

title: Underwater astonishments - David Gallo

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the ocean has been explored by humans?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract prey

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid being eaten

options.label: C
options.text: To communicate with other creatures

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A way of sliding across the bottom using waves and shadows

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: To attract prey

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid being eaten

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Phenology and nature's shifting rhythms - Regina Brinker

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for observing the timing of biological events in relation to changes in season and climate?

options.label: A
options.text: Ecology

options.label: B
options.text: Phenology

options.label: C
options.text: Botany

options.label: D
options.text: Zoology

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs 1 day earlier than usual

options.label: B
options.text: It occurs 5 days earlier than usual

options.label: C
options.text: It occurs 10 days earlier than usual

options.label: D
options.text: It occurs 15 days earlier than usual

options.label: B
options.text: Earlier fade of cherry blossoms in Washington D.C.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased revenue from agriculture

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased sales of winter clothing

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of the change in timing of the oak tree's bud burst on the winter moth caterpillars?

options.label: A
options.text: They hatch 5 days earlier than before

options.label: B
options.text: They hatch 10 days earlier than before

options.label: C
options.text: They hatch 15 days earlier than before

options.label: D
options.text: They hatch at the same time as before

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the delay in the pied flycatcher birds' chicks hatching compared to the winter moth caterpillars?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The bird population remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: The bird population decreases by up to 10%

options.label: D
options.text: The bird population decreases by up to 90%

title: Activation energy: Kickstarting chemical reactions - Vance Kite

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the energy required to initiate a chemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Transition energy

options.label: B
options.text: Activation energy

options.label: C
options.text: Reaction energy

options.label: D
options.text: Molecular energy

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of enzymes in chemical reactions?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the activation energy

options.label: B
options.text: To lower the activation energy and speed up the reaction

options.label: C
options.text: To provide energy for the reaction

options.label: D
options.text: To slow down the reaction

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the unstable state of a molecule during a chemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Transition state

options.label: B
options.text: Stable state

options.label: C
options.text: Reactive state

options.label: D
options.text: Molecular state

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a strategy used by enzymes to lower the activation energy?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a microenvironment

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the concentration

multiple-choice.question: What does the "S" stand for in the MODS Squad, a team of enzymes that help speed up chemical reactions?

options.label: A
options.text: Speeding reactions

options.label: B
options.text: Straining bonds

options.label: C
options.text: Stabilizing molecules

options.label: D

title: How we see color - Colm Kelleher

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why the region where the red and green lights overlap appears yellow to us?

options.label: A
options.text: The physical properties of light itself

options.label: B
options.text: The interaction between the red and green light waves

options.label: C
options.text: The way our brain processes the signals from the cone cells in the retina

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of yellow light in the region

multiple-choice.question: What type of cells in the retina are responsible for detecting colors?

options.label: A
options.text: Rod cells

options.label: B
options.text: Cone cells

options.label: C
options.text: Both rod and cone cells

options.label: D
options.text: Neither rod nor cone cells

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we detect colors in low-light conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cone cells are not sensitive enough

options.label: B
options.text: Because the rod cells take over and can only detect light or no light

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain is not able to process the signals from the cone cells

options.label: D
options.text: Because the physical properties of light change in low-light conditions

multiple-choice.question: How many different types of cone cells are there in the human retina?
Why is it useful for TV manufacturers to know about the properties of human vision?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they can create TVs that can display infinitely many colors

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can create TVs that can display only three colors

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can create TVs that can simulate the real world using only three colors

options.label: D
options.text: Because they can create TVs that can display colors in low-light conditions

title: You are your microbes - Jessica Green and Karen Guillemin

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cellulolytic bacteria in the gut microbial community?

options.label: A
options.text: To extract energy from simple sugars

options.label: B
options.text: To break down cellulose into simple sugars

options.label: C
options.text: To convert simple sugars into chemicals like alcohol and hydrogen gas

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb energy released by other microbes

multiple-choice.question: What determines the membership of our gut microbial community?

options.label: A
options.text: Only our genetic makeup

options.label: B
options.text: Only the microbes we encounter throughout our lives

options.label: C
options.text: Only the food we eat

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of our genetic makeup, the microbes we encounter, and the food we eat

multiple-choice.question: What happens to gut microbial communities with only a few different types of workers?

options.label: A
options.text: They function more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: They are more resistant to diseases

options.label: C
options.text: They are less likely to cause chronic gut inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: They do not function well

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a food that requires a diverse gut microbial community to break down?

options.label: A
options.text: A lollipop

options.label: B
options.text: An apple

options.label: C
options.text: A piece of meat

options.label: D
options.text: A glass of milk

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential way to revitalize our microbial ecosystems in the gut?

options.label: A
options.text: Eating a diet high in simple sugars

options.label: B
options.text: Eating a varied diet of complex, plant-based foods

options.label: C
options.text: Taking antibiotics regularly

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding fermented foods
